Title: COVID-19: 30 new confirmed cases, number rises to 227 [Upd 1]
Content: (TAP) - Thirty new infection cases by COVID-19 have been reported till March 26, bringing the overall number of confirmed cases to 227, out of a total of 2,045 carried out tests, according to a Health Ministry press release. They are 55 cases recorded in the governorate of Tunis, 34 (Ariana), 23 (Ben Arous), 14 (Medenine), 17 (Sousse), 17 (Monastir), 11 (Sfax), 11 (Kebili),  06 (Tataouine), 11 (Bizerte), 04 (Gabes) , 04 Mahdia, 03 Manouba, 02 Kairouan, 03 Nabeul, 02 Zaghouan, 01 Gafsa, 02 Kef, 01 Sidi Bouzid, 06 Tozeur, the ministry said. The number of deaths is 06 persons; 01 in Sfax, 01 in Sousse, 01 in Ariana, 01 in Kef, 01 in Mahdia, and 01 in Tataouine, recalls the same source. Some 17,888 persons are in self-quarantine, 8,845 of whom have completed the quarantine period and 9,043 are still in isolation and under daily medical check-ups. The Ministry recalls the imperative to respect hygiene standards and calls on citizens to show responsibility and compliance with the general lock-down so as to combat the spread of coronavirus.

Title: Four governorates still COVID-19 free
Content: (TAP) - Four governorates, namely Beja, Jendouba, Siliana and Kasserine, have so far reported no cases of infection by COVID-19, according to data published on the Prime Ministry's website regarding the development of the health situation in the country.The Gafsa and Kef governorates both reported only one case while the governorates of Kairouan, Nabeul and Zaghouan each reported two cases, the same source specifies. The number of cases reported in other governorates varies between 3 and 7 cases, with the exception of 5 governorates where the number of infection cases has surpassed 12. The Tunis governorate reported 52 cases, followed by Ariana (33) and Ben Arous (17).The Health Ministry announced in a press release issued Thursday night the identification of 24 new infection cases, out of 309 conducted tests.

Title: COVID-19: 24 new confirmed cases, number rises to 197 (Mekki)
Content: (TAP) - The total number of people contaminated with COVID-19 throughout the country has risen to 197 with 24 new confirmed cases, according to a new assessment announced Thursday evening by Minister of Public Health Abdellatif Mekki. In a statement to private television channel Carthage+, Mekki said the new cases tested positive, out of a total of 308 tests carried out, citing official data provided in coordination with the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases. The minister said the tests were carried out in the laboratories of the Charles Nicolle Hospital and the Pasteur Institute in Tunis. According to a Health Ministry press release, the 197 confirmed cases are among 1,763 tested persons. Since the spread of the pandemic in the country, 5 deaths due to the COVId-19 were recorded in 5 different governorates, namely Ariana, Kef, Mahdia, Sfax and Sousse. Geographically, the 197 confirmed cases are spread over 18 governorates. The highest number of cases were reported in Greater Tunis with 105 cases shared out between Tunis (52), Ariana (33), Ben Arous (17) and Manouba (3). The remaining cases were reported in Sousse (16), Monastir (14), Medenine (14), Sfax (11), Kebili (11), Tataouine (6), Bizerte (4), Gabes (4), Mahdia (4), Kairouan (2), Nabeul (2), Zaghouan (2), Gafsa (1) and Kef (1). According to the ministry, the monitoring measures of Tunisian repatriates helped till March 25, place 17,859 persons in self-quarantine, 7,692 of whom completed their quarantine period and the remaining 10,167 are still under health control nationwide. The ministry reiterated call for the Tunisians to comply with the hygiene and protection measures against COVID-19.In this difficult health situation, the ministry "relies on the awarness of the citizens and urge them to shoulder their collective responsibility by complying with the general lock-down measures."

Title: "No financial constraints that prevent payment of social subsidies" (Habib Kchaou)
Content: (TAP) - Social Affairs Minister, Habib Kchaou, told a plenary session held Thursday at the House of People's Representatives (HPR), that the setting of the date of March 30 for the payment of social allowances to their beneficiaries is due to strictly organisational, logistical and technical reasons, and not to the lack of funds.Kchaou said that the government has mobilised funds worth 150 million dinars to distribute them to about 900 thousand families, as well as 350 million dinars for the benefit of workers threatened by technical unemployment".He mentioned the approval of a specific increase of 50 dinars per allowance, for the benefit of 260 thousand poor families who have already received their allowances. Consultations are underway with the Tunisian Post Office for the payment of specific allowances for the benefit of 623 thousand families in the amount of 200 dinars per allowance, from March 30 .Kchaou also stressed that "there is no financial constraint that prevents the payment of subsidies to workers laid off in the context of technical unemployment. These subsidies will be paid once the procedures are completed and successively depending on the receipt of new applications, he explained.He stressed that all these measures were adopted "in record time, shortly after the decision of general lockdown in prevention against the Coronavirus", praising the efforts made by the Tunisian administration to iron out the difficulties that hamper the payment of social subsidies.

Title: Potential Covid-19 patients banned from accessing emergency wards (ministry)
Content: (TAP)-  The Health Ministry took necessary measures to ban potential coronavirus patients from accessing emergency wards in different hospitals, Director-General of Public Health Facilities Mohamed Mokdad said.Tents were set up outside hospitals to detect potential cases pending tests, the official told TAP.Other spaces were fitted out close to emergency services to test patients before they are allowed access to one of the departments.

Title: Covid-19: Charles Nicolle Hospital doctor tests positive
Content: (TAP) -Director General of the Charles Nicolle Hospital in Tunis Souad Sadrawi confirmed Wednesday that a doctor in the department of nephrology and urinary tract had contracted the new coronavirus at the hospital and that a second doctor in the same department, suspected of being infected, had been subjected to self-quarantine.In a statement to TAP, Sadrawi indicated that the infected doctor, who was in his sixties, had made an individual decision to self-isolate since March 19, despite the absence of symptoms of the epidemic at that time. Tests carried out on Tuesdaday turned up positive. The second doctor in the same department had also made the decision to isolate himself while waiting for the results of his tests, Sadrawi added. In this regard, she said an urgent decision had been taken to sterilise the nephrology and urinary tract department, subject all staff working there, including the medical and paramedical staff to self-isolation and ensure that all protective equipment is provided for patients and hospital workers. Since the spread of the virus, only urgent cases have been accepted in this department, she specified.As the number of confirmed cases of infection increases, hospitals will adopt protocols specific to the needs of each facility, the same source indicated.

Title: Coronavirus : second patient recovers
Content: (TAP)- The second Covid-19 patient recovered, Director of the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases Nissaf  Ben Alaya Wednesday told TAP. The number of recoveries is poised to  increase in the coming days, she added.The patient is a woman who was contaminated by her husband.  The man, native of Boumerdes (  governorate of Mahdia) died Monday at Farhat Hachat hospital, Ben Alaya said. The first recovery was recorded in Sfax.Ben Alaya said the Health Ministry will actively investigate each case it is notified about in a bid to expand the scope of testing.

Title: Health measures taken to prevent spread of coronavirus in refugee shelters (UNHCR)
Content: (TAP) - The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) announced that health and preventive measures have been taken to prevent the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) in accommodation centres for refugees and asylum seekers in Tunisia.Sanitary products and equipment have been provided to places where refugees were accommodated, particularly in Medenine and Zarzis, in order to support the efforts of the State in caring for refugees, said a statement issued jointly by the UNHCR office in Tunis and its partners, the Arab Institute for Human Rights, the Tunisian Refugee Council and the Tunisian Association for Social Management and Social Stability.According to this statement, disinfection and cleaning operations in the accommodation centres have been intensified with the help and contribution of the refugees.Awareness-raising campaigns are being conducted through documents and leaflets containing information on prevention methods and hygiene rules that have been distributed to the people accommodated, as well as through SMS and videos posted on the pages of the Arab Institute for Human Rights in three languages (Arabic, French and English).A doctor will be available on site in all refugee accommodation centres for 4 hours a day to ensure awareness and care, and 3 sterilised premises will house cases subject to isolation, in cooperation with the Tunisian authorities, the press release reads.

Title: Tunisian doctors start using Chloroquine under clinical trials to treat coronavirus
Content: (TAP)– Tunisian doctors have started using anti-malaria drug Chloroquine, in combination with other drugs, as part of clinical trials to treat subjects infected with COVID-19, Director-General of Primary Health Care at the Health Ministry Chokri Hamouda told TAP on Tuesday.Hammouda added these tests are being carried out by a group of scientists and researchers in Tunisia, in coordination with the National Laboratory for Drug Control (LNCM), the National Centre for Pharmacovigilance and the National Authority for health Assessment and Accreditation (INEAS).The Directorate of Primary Health "has acquired sufficient quantities of Chloroquine, thanks to the support of the Central Pharmacy and the Central Bank," he pointed out.Hammouda previously told TAP the use of Chloroquine should only be allowed over a medical prescription issued by medical specialists among participants in clinical trials, noting that non-specialist doctors are not authorised to prescribe this medicine, in order to avoid possible side effects.These clinical trials come following the decision of Minister of Health Abdellatif Mekki to use this drug to treat patients with the coronavirus.Mekki had indicated that the departments of Health and Higher Education and Scientific Research have allocated funds worth 2.5 million dinars to finance studies and research on the use of Chloroquine in the treatment of patients with the COVID-19.

Title: Coronavirus prevention: BCT grants Health Ministry 50 million dinars in foreign currency
Content: (TAP)- The Central Bank of Tunisia (BCT) has granted the Ministry of Health 50 million dinars in foreign currency to import medical supplies needed to prevent the coronavirus (COVID-19) from China, said Director of Primary Health Care at the Ministry of Health Chokri Hammouda. Speaking to TAP Tuesday, Hammouda said the shipment, which will arrive in Tunisia early next week by private plane, will meet the needs of the country's health structures and institutions for several months.He said the medical supplies seized by the economic control teams are made available to hospitals.He reported that the Central Pharmacy has acquired a stock of medical supplies needed for virus prevention, despite the shortage of such supplies due to high global demand.

Title: Urology and Pathological Anatomy departments at Rabta Hospital shut down, staff in quarantine
Content: (TAP)-The Rabta Hospital has shut down its urology department, after a case of infection with the coronavirus (COVID-19) was detected in a patient who was admitted there.The Pathological Anatomy department of the hospital was also closed over suspected infection with the virus by an employee, hospital director Mongi Khemiri told TAP Tuesday.A disinfection operation of the two departments is currently underway, while the medics and paramedics working there have been placed in quarantine, Khemiri said, adding that screening tests have already been carried out.Khemiri said the hospital's urology department was closed yesterday Monday under instructions from the Ministry of Health, after the 41-year-old patient, who was admitted to the department last Wednesday night tested positive for the virus.The closure of the pathological anatomy department also comes after the suspected infection of one its employees with the virus. That employee was in contact with a person outside the hospital who subsequently tested positive for the coronavirus.Khemiri said the pathological anatomy department of Rabta Hospital was closed for sterilisation, stating that no symptoms of virus infection have appeared in the medics and paramedics of the two departments, who were placed in quarantine.

Title: Kchaou and Tabboubi discuss social measures for low-income workers
Content: (TAP)– Secretary General of the Tunisian General Labour Union (UGTT) and Minister of Social Affairs Mohamed Habib Kchaou, on Tuesday, discussed ways to support low-income workers and underprivileged social groups, said a statement by the UGTT.Tabboubi stressed the importance of implementing measures for vulnerable social groups during this period of general lockdown, in order to preserve the values of solidarity and cohesion within society.During the meeting, emphasis was placed on the need for private institutions to abide by the rules of the general lockdown, especially those which do not exercise vital activities in order to protect workers against the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19), in accordance with the recommendations of the Health Ministry.

Title: First public videoconferencing platform hosted in Tunisia "VISIO.TN," launched
Content: (TAP)- The first public videoconferencing platform hosted in Tunisia "visio.tn" has just been launched by DYXIS - provider of cloud solutions.This is a citizen initiative, carried out by a dynamic team that has been working tirelessly over the past few days to offer Tunisians a free solution dedicated to all public companies, public education institutions and higher education establishments, as well as videoconferencing organisers, according to a press release published by the initiators of this platform.The platform "www.visio.tn is a solution for teleworking, videoconferencing, virtual presentations, meetings and all other types of meetings, which is made available to all Tunisians during this period of general lockdown decreed by the Tunisian authorities to contain the spread of coronavirus.All data and exchanges are encrypted and secure and transmitted only through the national network, the press release states.Tunisian companies, educational institutions, universities will now be able to create rooms for meetings, learning or make presentations and exchange documents via this platform, which is easily accessible from PCs, smartphones and tablets via Wi-Fi or 4G.Among the functionalities of this platform that allow its users to carry out effective and interactive videoconferences, there are also the creation of public and private videoconferences, Interaction via webcam (sound and image), sharing of documents and presentations: Powerpoint, PDF, docs, presenter management and videoconference handling, local messaging and chat system, integration of images and videos for group viewing, recording of the entire videoconference, as well as the possibility of extension to invite users via phone call (audio) and the possibility of sharing live demos.Note that DYXIS DATA EXPERIENCE is a Cloud Solutions Provider which is currently positioned as the reference of the managed cloud on the Tunisian market in terms of high availability and quality of support.

Title: COVID-19 : 25 new confirmed cases, bringing overall number to 114
Content: (TAP)-The Health Ministry announced on Tuesday on its official page that 25 new confirmed cases of the coronavirus infection have been reported in Tunisia out of a total of 124 new tests carried out, bringing the overall number to 114 (74 imported cases and 39 domestic) out of a total of 1,211 tests conducted. According to the Ministry, the governorate of Tunis has the highest number of inections with 34 confirmed cases, followed by the governorate of Ariana (20), Ben Arous (12), Medenine (09), Tataouine (06), Sousse (06), Monastir (07), Sfax (05), Mahdia (03), Kairouan (02) and Bizerte (03).The governorates of Nabeul, Gafsa, Gabes, Kebili, Manouba and Zaghouan each have only one case (1).Out of the overall number of confirmed cases, one patient has been cured and 11 others are hospitalised. The total number of deaths so far is 3 (1 in Sfax, 1 in Sousse and 1 in Ariana), the ministry specified, adding that as part of the follow-up of persons who returned to Tunisia, 15,952 have been subjected to self-quarantine, 5,438 have completed their fortnight and 10,514 are still under regular medical supervision.In order to better combat the spread of the new coronavirus, the Ministry stresses the need to comply with the general lock-down measure and health and hygiene recommendations.

Title: Fourteen resuscitation beds at Charles Nicolle Hospital reserved for Covid-19 patients (Hospital Director)
Content: (TAP)- The Charles Nicolle Hospital à Tunis reserved 14 resuscitation beds for Covid-19 patients in     one of its departments, announced hospital director general Souad SadraouiIn a statement to TAP, the official pointed out that the ward reserved for Covid-19 patients also contains 8 surgical beds in case of need, specifying that the hospital has also reserved another well-equipped ward as part of fight against the spread of the new coronavirus.She further indicated that the hospital services have set up a coronavirus prevention protocol to facilitate the care of patients by all staff without fear of contamination.In this regard, she stressed that the hospital has adhered to the national strategy against coronavirus launched by the Health Ministry and is endeavouring to implement all its items.Sadraoui said that to date, the hospital's emergency has not received Covid-19 infected people.

Title: "We will suffer human losses among our relatives and friends if general lockdown is not fully respected" (Nissaf Ben Alaya)
Content: (TAP) – «We will suffer human losses, among our relatives and friends and we will all be at risk in case the general lockdown is not fully respected," Nissaf Ben Alaya, Director of the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases said on Monday, in response to the failure to comply with that measure, especially in regions that have recorded horizontal transmissions. Speaking at the periodic press briefing held Monday, Ben Alaya urged citizens and all law enforcers to ensure full respect for general lockdown "based on a sense of responsibility and not a procedure that limits freedom."She added "it is still possible to redress the situation by committing to respect this measure, otherwise the consequences will be disastrous." Ben Alaya stressed that the current situation can be rectified by observing lockdown and enforcing the law, warning of the consequences of violating the provisions of this procedure, especially in some areas where transmission is now horizontal and could broaden the parameter of virus transmission to other places. She said that Tunisia has so far recorded 89 confirmed cases of coronavirus (COVID-19), noting that there are certainly other undetected cases that are spreading the virus. "Hence the absolute necessity to respect the lockdown," she insisted. The official further stressed that the general lockdown applies to all regions of the country, especially those areas where the contamination has become horizontal, requiring stricter enforcement of lockdown. She noted that countries that have committed themselves to the strict application of general lockdown have managed to limit the spread of the virus, and that "countries that have approached it laxly have suffered heavy casualties".

Title: PM meets with UGTT S-G and UTICA and UTAP presidents
Content: (TAP) – Prime Minister Elyes Fakhfakh met Monday at the Government Palace in La Kasbah with Secretary-General of the Tunisian General Labour Union (UGTT) Nourredine Taboubi, President of the Tunisian Union of Industry, Trade and Handicrafts (UTICA) Samir Majoul and President of the Tunisian Union of Agriculture and Fisheries (UTAP), Abdelmajid Zar. The Prime Minister stressed the importance of stepping up consultations with national organisations in this delicate phase underwent by the country to deal with the health, social and economic consequences of the coronavirus (COVID-19). He also emphasised the need to uphold national unity and to give priority to preserving the health safety of Tunisians and reducing the impact of this pandemic on the country.

Title: Coronavirus:  total confirmed cases rise to 89
Content: (TAP)– The overall number of confirmed cases of infection with COVID-19 has risen to 89, after 14 more cases were recorded on March 22, Director of the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases Nissaf Ben Alaya said at a press briefing Monday.Out of 126 tests, 14 were positive. These include 29 domestic and 60 imported cases, she added.The cases of contamination are spread over 16 governorates as follows: 16 cases in Ariana, 2 cases in Kairouan, 1 case in Gafsa (recovered), 3 cases in Mahdia, 29 cases in Tunis, 2 cases in Bizerte, 5 cases in Tataouine, 5 cases in Sousse, 5 cases in Monastir, 8 cases in Ben Arous, 5 cases in Medenine, 4 cases in Sfax, 1 case in Kebili, 1 case in Gabes and 1 case in Nabeul and 1 case in Manouba.Eleven infected people have been hospitalised to date, she added, recalling that only one case has been cured.Until March 22, about 14,000 people have been placed in home-isolation, including more than 5,000 who have completed their period of home-isolation and about 8,800 still comply with this measure, she added.Ben Alaya said 3 people died from a coronavirus contraction, until Sunday, March 22, the first of whom was recorded in Sousse. She was a 72-year-old woman who arrived from Turkey and died on March 18.The second case was recorded in Sfax: a septuagenarian man who died on March 21. The third case was recorded in Ariana governorate, a 60-year-old man who died on March 22.Ben Alaya noted the existence of several breaches in the application of the measures announced by the State related to total confinement, especially in the contaminated areas.She warned against the non-application of the law and the general lockdown. "In the event of non-application, each Tunisian risks losing one of his relatives and no family will be safe," she said, indicating that the fight against this virus is a shared responsibility between citizens and the various stakeholders.

Title: Coronavirus: Soukra clinic shuts down, staff quarantined after French patient tests positive
Content: (TAP)- Soukra clinic was shut down on Friday and its staff quarantined upon decision of the Health Ministry. The move came as one of its patients tested positive for Covid-19, said Director-General Rachid Mannai.All staff were placed under quarantine after tests were carried out, Mannai added. A French national was admitted on March 11 and had surgery the following day (March 12) without showing any symptoms of Covid-19 infection.

Title: Coronavirus:  total confirmed cases rise to 89
Content: (TAP)- The overall number of confirmed cases of infection with COVID-19 has risen to 89, after 14 more cases were recorded on March 22, Director of the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases Nissaf Ben Alaya said at a press briefing Monday. Out of 126 tests, 14 were positive.  These include  29 domestic and 60 imported cases, she added.

Title: Scientific Research: National initiative to find innovative Solutions to Coronavirus control launched
Content: (TAP) - A national initiative was launched Sunday to mobilise means and capacities of the scientific research sector to find practical, innovative and rapid solutions to support national efforts to combat the spread of the new coronavirus in Tunisia.This initiative, launched after a meeting held between the ministers of higher education and scientific research, health, industry and SMEs and communication and digital transition technologies, is a coordination and management mechanism that will be expanded later in the framework of a government initiative to which all other sectors will adhere, says a statement issued by the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research.The same source says that innovative research projects will be launched in the coming days in partnership with the health, technology and industry sectors to find treatment, develop vaccines, manufacture medical devices, develop digital applications and make the most of artificial intelligence techniques in the fight against the coronavirus.At the meeting, attended by the Director General of the Deposit and Consignment Fund, it was also agreed to allocate significant funds to carry out the first batch of projects under the public-private partnership, the statement added.

Title: COVID-19: three clusters of virus found in Greater Tunis
Content: (TAP) - Three clusters of COVID-19 virus have been discovered in Greater Tunis, they are: Berges du Lac, Marsa and Soukra, said Director General of Basic Health at the Public Health Ministry Chokri Hammouda. The reported cases are caused by horizontal contamination, without being able to detect the source of this infection, the official told TAP on Sunday. The Health Ministry had announced earlier on Sunday the transition to phase 3 of the Covid-19 pandemic, he indicated. A rise in the number of those infected is expected in the coming days, according to the official who considered that the arrival of those repatriated could worsen the spread of the virus among the citizens and even in health structures.Hammouda further reported the preventive measures against the Covid-19 taken by the Health Ministry in the hospitals and society in general.To this end, he spoke about a preventive plan devised in coordination with the public sector.According to the official, Tunisia has entered an advanced phase in its fight against the Covid-19 pandemic that requires sharing the responsibilities of all stakeholders. Wide powers will be granted to regional directors so as to avoid the spread of the virus at a greater level, he indicated.

Title: 50 Tunisians returning from Canada quarantined in Jebel Oust health complex
Content: (TAP) - The Jebel Oust health complex accommodated on Sunday 50 Tunisians who returned from Canada.Men, women and children are expected to stay in a mandatory 14-day quarantine period as a preventive measure against Covid-19, Regional Health Director in Zaghouan Hager Missaoui stated to TAP A suspected infection case among these individuals will be tested following a first diagnosis at the airport. The man was isolated in a room at the health complex, pending the results of tests due on Monday.  Before the arrival of these Tunisians, the health complex was totally evacuated of patients so as to protect them from risks of infection with the virus. The above mentioned 50 persons will be totally taken care of, under the supervision of the health services and will benefit from a daily medical follow-up, the same source indicated.

Title: COVID-19: Toll-free numbers to be available to families to ensure psychological care" (ministry)
Content: (TAP) - "The Ministry of Women, Family, Children and the Elderly is currently in the process of setting up toll-free numbers to be available to families to ensure their psychological care," Minister Asma Shiri Laabidi announced on Sunday. This initiative was launched jointly with the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) Tunis Office and the phone service operators, she said in a statement to TAP. Laabidi explained that these toll-free numbers are intended "to reduce the psychological pressure related to the coronavirus spread," stressing that the initiative will only continue during the period of general lock-down. In another regard, the minister indicated that in order to provide more assistance to low-income families, her department is striving, in coordination with the various regional structures, to collect the aid and hand it over to the sides entrusted with its distribution, such as the Ministry of Social Affairs and the Tunisian Union of Social Solidarity. A set of measures has been taken, in particular for the benefit of the elderly, women victims of violence and children," she added.

Title: Covid-19: Infection cases up to 75, 3 deaths (Health Ministry)
Content: (TAP)- The number of confirmed cases of coronavirus infection has risen to 75, announced Sunday Director of the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases Nissaf Ben Alaya, specifying that 2 new deaths had been reported bringing the number to 3 deaths.Out of 132 tests, 15 new cases tested positive on March 21, they are 31 local cases and 54 imported cases, she said.The cases of infection are spread over 15 governorates as follows: 15 cases in Ariana, 2 cases in Kairouan, 1 case in Gafsa, 3 cases in Mahdia, 22 cases in Tunis, 2 cases in Bizerte, 5 cases in Tataouine, 5 cases in Sousse, 5 cases in Monastir, 5 cases in Ben Arous, 3 cases in Medenine, 4 cases in Sfax, 1 case in Kebili, 1 case in Gabes and 1 case in Nabeul.Seven (7) infected persons have been hospitalised at the Abderrahmen Mami Hospital in Ariana and 3 others at the Farhat Hached Hospital in Sousse, Ben Alaya indicated, specifying that only one (1) case has been cured and that 33 of the contaminated cases are women.Until March 21, some 12,395 people have been placed in self-quarantine, including 4,753 who have completed the period and over 7,642 are still uner this health measure, said the same source.Two new deaths from coronavirus contraction had been confirmed untill March 21, Nissaf Ben Alaya underlined, specifying that the second case had been reported in Sfax of a man in his seventies who died on March 21 and the third death had been registered in Ariana of a 60-year-old man who died on March 22.The first death case was recorded in Sousse of a 72-year-old woman who had arrived from Turkey and died on March 18.

Title: General lockdown for over 10 million Tunisians as of Sunday
Content: (TAP) – Prime Minister Elyes Fakhfakh announced on Saturday night that the general lockdown is a measure that involves all Tunisians, with the exception of about 15% of the population that will continue to work so as to ensure the smooth running of vital sectors, such as security, health, agro-food, water, electricity, banks, etc. The general lockdown is a preventive measure aimed to ensure the people's security and the country's stability, this is why it is imperative to stay home and reduce the movement, Fakhfakh said addressing the Nation on the eve of the enforcement of the general lockdown measure. «The general health lockdown» decided on Friday during a national security council, is a measure that «will also help us conduct some 10 thousand screening tests and thus make a sample,» he explained. "This measure of great importance will help us identify the rise in the number of those infected and the  progress of the disease,» he inidcated.  «We can thus take lead and prepare ourselves for all scenarios.» Fakhfakh called Tunisians to comply with the health measures and to be patient, interdependent and generous. «There is no victory without sacrifice,»  he pointed out. «However, I am still convinced that we will this battle and we will come out of it stronger and more united.»   The general lockdown in Tunisia will be enforced as of March 22 till April 4, the Prime Ministry announced last Friday.

Title: Chloroquine has no marketing approval for COVID-19 treatment (Chokri Hammouda)
Content: (TAP)– Chloroquine has no marketing approval from the Pharmacy and Medicines Unit of the Health Ministry as a treatment for the new coronavirus (COVID-19), said Director-General of Primary Health Care at the Health Ministry Chokri Hamouda. Hammouda told TAP this drug is initially intended for the treatment of malaria; it will be adopted to treat new coronavirus patients within the framework of therapeutic research led by specialised doctors in Tunisia.He recalled that there is currently no drug that has marketing approval for the treatment of the COVID-19 around the world, adding researchers are carrying out tests, in accordance with the rules of ethics and the laws in force.Hammouda stressed that "this medicine is given only on medical prescriptions issued by specialised doctors, participating in clinical research experiments," noting non-specialist doctors are not entitled to prescribe it, to avoid any side effects."Director General of the Central Pharmacy Khalil Ammous, on Saturday, told TAP the Ministry of Health requested that the imported Chloroquine be made available to it, saying the Central Pharmacy has a sufficient stock of the drug.Health Minister Abdellatif Mekki had announced that a certain number of medical services in Tunisia have decided to use Chloroquine to treat patients infected with the COVID-19.

Title: UGTT urges strict measures to ensure enforcement of general lockdown
Content: (TAP)– The Tunisian General Labour Union (UGTT), on Saturday, called on the President of the Republic and the Prime Minister to explain in detail the general lockdown and put in place strict measures to enforce it.The UGTT said it in a statement it considered the measures announced on Friday unclear, calling for a ban on gatherings and a halt to all non-vital activities, including means of transport which are still congested.The labour union stressed the need to hold accountable anyone who violates the lockdown provisions, while specifying cases of force majeure.The UGTT called on the citizens concerned to comply with the lockdown measures to protect their health and that of their families.It stressed the importance of developing a strategy to secure supply and control food distribution channels and considering monopoly of commodities a crime rather than an offence."It is also necessary to take urgent social measures for those who have lost their jobs and to mobilise all financial resources for public hospitals in order to successfully stem the pandemic," the statement added.The UGTT also recommended issuing, as soon as possible, a law or a government decree to impose a bottom-up tax on wealth that will be intended to support public hospitals in their efforts to combat the coronavirus.

Title: "Non-compliance with self-quarantine may lead country to disaster" (Health Minister)
Content: (TAP) - Non-compliance with the self-quarantine rules may, under the current circumstances, lead the country to a disaster, Health Minister Abdellatif Mekki said Saturday.Speaking at a press briefing held at the headquarters of the ministry, Mekki pointed out that the issue is not only related to non-abidance by self-isolation rules but also to possible wrong contact details provided by travellers while filling in forms distributed to them at airports.Due to the non-compliance with the measures required by several people, the State has decided to place the quarantined in spaces fitted out by authorities with effective living conditions."These are tough measures yet there are no other options if we want to protect the entire country and society," Mekki underscored, calling on Tunisians to respect the rules.These measures will ensure that medical teams monitor any person exhibiting symptoms of COVID19.The refusal by several Tunisian nationals, Friday, to comply with the Health Ministry’s instructions to stay in quarantine spaces fitted out by relevant authorities could be explained by the fact that this is first experience since the announcement of the new measures, Mekki explained.The minister called on Tunisian nationals, who were repatriated, to show more cooperation and understanding amid the tough situation the world is facing.All governors and local health directors as well as the Ministries of the Interior, Defence, Justice, Higher Education, Education, Training, Transport, Employment, Youth and Sport are committed to this measure of collective quarantine, El Mekki indicated.A working session will, on Saturday, bring together the various ministries concerned so as to discuss ways to overcome the failures that occurred in Friday's repatriation process.Tunisians, who were repatriated Friday, refused to be quarantined in collective spaces fitted out by the relevant authorities.

Title: Coronavirus: potential use of malaria drug Chloroquine  mulled (minister)
Content: (TAP)– The use of Chloroquine, a malaria drug, to treat coronavirus patients is being considered, Health Minister Aldellatif El Mekki Saturday told a press briefing.The ministries of health and scientific research earmarked 2.5 million dinars in funding to finance research and experiments on the use of Chloroquine in coronavirus treatment."The ministry approved the use of Chloroquine in specific cases," he said.El Mekki added, in this vein, that  some wards in a number of hospitals were made available for infected people."Resuscitation will be offered to all severe cases despite modest means available," he added.Patients with coronavirus symptoms will be detected at the entrance of emergency services to receive needed care.A monitoring unit, including doctors and administrators, will be set up in each hospital to monitor the implementation of the ministry's strategies, he emphasised.People with chronic renal failure facing a possible Covid-19 infection will have a specific healthcare protocol.

Title: Covid-19: lockdown strategic move in spite of high costs  (minister)
Content: (TAP)- Measures taken Friday by the National Security Council will be very costly, Health Minister Abdellatif El Mekki said. "There will be a high economic and security cost"  and losses may amount to hundreds of billions of dinars and take a heavy toll on an already ailing economy, he added, but the State does not hesitate when it comes to the interests of citizens. This is why, a strategic nationwide lockdown decision was made notwithstanding the difficult economic situation.This full lockdown will be coupled with exceptional measures in order to guarantee security and the basic needs of everyday life. Citizens may leave their homes to buy foodtsuff and get medication but they cannot         leave without a valid reason, El Mekki said.The government will announce a string of measures tailored to the needs of  deprived groups.

Title: Health Ministry ensures medical monitoring of repatriated Tunisian passengers  (Ben Alaya)
Content: (TAP) - Nearly 1,000 Tunisian nationals had been repatriated through several evacuation flights, said Director of the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases Nissaf Ben Alaya, specifying that several among them had not complied with the quarantine measures.She pointed in this regard, to the shortcomings at the level of coordination between the various stakeholders.     "Some people have refused to comply with the instructions," said Ben Alaya, recalling that collective spaces have been set up by the authorities with the necessary means and equipment in addition to the human and medical competences mobilised in these quarantine places.The Health Ministry is monitoring the situation of returnees, thanks to the contact details on the health cards upon arrival at the airport, Ben Alaya said."With the exception of one person who provided a false telephone number, all other passengers arriving at the airport are contacted by the ministry to explain the rules of self-isolation," she specified.The department had also set up an application to monitor the situation of these people in self-isolation, the same source added.

Title: Covid-19: 6 new confirmed cases, bringing total number to 60 [Upd 1]
Content: (TAP)- The number of confirmed cases of coronavirus infection has risen to 60, Director of the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases Nissaf Ben Alaya announced Saturday.Out of 126 tests, 6 new cases have tested positive on March 20. They are 19 local cases and 41 imported cases, she specified, adding that they are all taken care of.The cases are spread over 13 governorates as follows: 16 cases in Ariana, 2 cases in Kairouan, 1 case in Gafsa, 3 cases in Mahdia, 17 cases in Tunis, 2 cases in Bizerte, 4 cases in Tataouine, 5 cases in Sousse, 3 cases in Monastir, 4 cases in Ben Arous, 3 cases in Medenine, 1 case in Sfax and 1 case in Nabeul.The average age of the infected persons is 55.6 years, revealed Ben Alaya, explaining that the age of the infected persons varies between 3 months and 83 year old. She indicated that half of those infected are women. Out of the 60 cases affected by coronavirus, 50 are of Tunisian nationality.Until March 19, some 11,863 people have been placed in quarantine, including 4,422 who had completed the quarantine period and over 7,441 still comply with this health measure, Ben Alaya recalled.

Title: COVID-19: fifteen confirmed cases in Tunis governorate and 92 quarantined
Content: (TAP)- "The Tunis governorate has so far recorded 15 confirmed cases of infection with the new coronavirus (COVID-19), out of a total of 54 cases in the country and not 17 as previously announced by the Ministry of Health,” local health director in Tunis Tarken Ben Nasr said Friday.Speaking to TAP, the official added that these confirmed cases are under medical surveillance and their condition is normal.92 other people aged between 4 and 77 years who were in direct contact with the infected persons are currently in self-quarantine, he said.Ben Nasr reported that the governorate of Tunis is willing to assist the infected patients in case of health complications and to contain the pandemic at the level of Greater Tunis. In this context, he said that sick people will be transferred to public hospitals and intensive care units as well as private clinics which have expressed their willingness to admit and care for the sick.  In addition, the local health director called on citizens to respect the quarantine measures and recommendations of the Ministry of Health to fight against the spread of the disease.

Title: Telethon to raise money for anti-coronavirus fund: 4,710.597 Tunisian dinars raised till 11 a.m.
Content: (TAP) – The value of donations for the Anti-coronavirus Fund granted as part of a telethon broadcast on Friday morning on the National TV Channel, has reached 4,710.597 Tunisian dinars.Organised at the initiative of the Independent High Broadcasting Authority (HAICA) under the supervision of the National TV and with the participation of various audiovisual institutions, the telethon will continue till Saturday at dawn. The amount to be raised will be used to support the efforts of public health institutions in combating Covid-19.According to HAICA President Nouri Lajmi, this initiative also aims to raise citizens’ awareness about the importance of their role in combating this pandemic through the respect of preventive health measures and recommendations.

Title: Covid-19: Infection cases rise to 54 (Health Ministry) [Upd 1]
Content: (TAP) - The number of confirmed infected cases by coronavirus has increased to 54, Director of the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases Nissaf Ben Alaya announced Friday at a press briefing.There are 18 local and 36 imported cases, she said, specifying that Tunisia has also recorded the recovery of the first case of the virus.Out of 79 tests carried out Thursday, March 19, 2020, 15 cases tested positive, she added, specifying that all these persons are taken care of.The cases are spread over 13 governorates as follows: 13 cases in Ariana, 2 cases in Kairouan, 1 case in Gafsa, 3 cases in Mahdia, 17 cases in Tunis, 2 cases in Bizerte, 4 cases in Tataouine, 4 cases in Sousse, 3 cases in Monastir, 2 cases in Ben Arous, 1 case in Medenine, 1 case in Sfax and 1 case in Nabeul.Seven persons among the contaminated cases were hospitalised, 4 among them at the Abderrahmen Mami Hospital in Ariana and 3 are at the Farhat Hached Hospital in Sousse.The average age of the contaminated persons is 45 years, revealed Ben Alaya, explaining that the age of the contaminated persons varies between 3 months and 83 year old.According to her, half of those infected are women. Out of the 54 cases, 44 are of Tunisian nationality.Until March 19, about 11,000 people had been placed in self-isolation, including 3,340 who have completed the period of self-isolation and more than 7,560 still comply with this health measure, she pointed out.Besides, Ben Alaya indicated that the name of Lotfi Mraihi is not on the list of names of persons who had carried out tests on coronavirus at reference laboratories. "We can only talk about a contaminated area when we have more than 10 confirmed cases in a limited geographical area," she specified, saying that confinement in certain areas is possible."Total confinement in all regions requires consultation and intervention by all regulatory authorities," she underlined.The official also stressed that the burial of infected persons is subject to a number of rules and exceptional measures.It should be recalled that a septuagenarian who arrived from Turkey died Wednesday in Sousse after being infected by coronavirus.This is the first death of an infected case in Tunisia, according to Ben Alaya who stressed that Tunisia is likely to move to the third epidemiological phase in case of non-compliance with the preventive measures announced by the State.

Title: First coronavirus-related death recorded in Tunisia  [Upd 1]
Content: (TAP)– The first coronavirus-related death was recorded in the country after results of the tests carried out on the body of the elderly woman who died Wednesday proved her infection, Director of the National Observatory for New and Emerging Diseases Nissaf Ben Alia said on Thursday evening.The woman, who recently returned from Turkey, had been in home-quarantine, she added.Regional health director in Sousse Sameh Rekik, on Wednesday, announced the death of a 72-year-old woman who had recently arrived from Turkey, saying she was suffering from chronic illnesses and that she had been in home-quarantine.Rekik said a health team moved to the woman's home, shortly before her death to transfer her to the hospital, adding tests carried out to determine the causes of her death showed it was due to infection with coronavirus. The Ministry of Health, on Thursday morning, announced the recovery of the first case of coronavirus in Tunisia and 10 more confirmed infections, bringing the overall number of cases to 39, taking into account the deceased woman.Ben Alaya said 8787 people have been placed in home-quarantine until Thursday, 5628 of them have already finished their isolation period, while 3,156 continue their quarantine, including 4 in hospitals.

Title: Coronavirus: Tunis governorate has highest number of infected people
Content: (TAP)- Tunis is topping the country’s governorates in terms of number of confirmed cases of infection with coronavirus (COVID-19), with 14 cases out of 39 recorded so far, according to the latest data on the developments of the pandemic in Tunisia, posted on the relevant website.The cases of infection recorded in the governorate of Tunis are divided between 9 imported cases and 5 cases of contamination by local contraction.Nine cases were recorded in the governorate of Ariana, 3 in the governorate of Mahdia, 2 cases per governorate in Kairouan, Bizerte and Sousse and 1 case per governorate in Ben Arous, Gafsa, Tataouine, Monastir, Sfax, Nabeul and Medenine, according to the same source. The number of persons placed in home-quarantine currently stands at 3159, while 5628 persons have already completed that measure.The 39 cases of infection with the virus (14 local and 25 imported), are divided almost equally between men and women, (19 women and 20 men).

Title: President Kais Saied meets PM and Parliament Speaker, discuss latest health developments
Content: (TAP)- The progress of the health situation and the effectiveness of the measures taken to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) were the focus of a meeting held Thursday at the Carthage Palace between President of the Republic Kais Saied, Prime Minister Elyes Fakhfakh and Speaker of the House of People’s Representatives (HPR) Rached Ghannouchi.An emphasis was also placed on the need to take all preventive measures to avert the infection with this dangerous virus and halt the pandemic, reads a press release of the Presidency of the Republic.

Title: Telehealth platform starts offering free online consultations
Content: (TAP)- A Tunisian telehealth platform started offering free online consultations on Wednesday. The platform, which has been operational since last February, opted for a section dedicated to online consultations to help sick people given the measures taken to halt the spread of Coronavirus, Founder and Director-General of Tobba.tn Imed El Abed told TAP. "This new section started operating with 4 volunteer doctors, including a surgeon. It is open to all specialists wishing to contribute to the State's anti-Covid-19  efforts, " he added.   This platform is a 100% Tunisian product, he underlined.

Title: Covid-19: first patient leaves hospital after full recovery
Content: (TAP)– The first patient who tested positive for the Covid-19 recovered and was discharged, said Head of the Infectious Diseases Service at Farhat Hached teaching hospital Amel Letaief.  Follow-up tests turned negative, she added.  A man in his forties native of Gafsa was the first to be infected in Tunisia. He returned in late February from Italy where he was infected. The patient was transferred on March 2 from Gafsa to Farhat Hached hospital where he was admitted to the infectious diseases ward.

Title: Ten more confirmed cases of COVID-19 recorded in Tunisia
Content: (TAP) - Ten more cases of infection with COVID-19 have been confirmed in Tunisia, Director of the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases Nissaf Ben Alaya announced at a press briefing Thursday. It is a single local case and 9 imported cases, she said, recalling that Tunisia has also recorded the recovery of the first case of contamination, thus bringing the total number to 38 cases. Twenty five cases are imported and 14 local cases, she specified. Out of 86 tests carried out on March 18, 10 cases have tested positive, she added, pointing out that all the contaminated persons are being taken care of. Up to March 18, 611 tests were carried out and 8,787 people have been placed in self-isolation, 5,628 of whom completed the self-isolation period and 3,159 are still complying with this health measure, according to the same source. Ben Alya indicated that Tunisia is likely to move to the 3rd epidemiological phase in case of non-application and non-compliance with the preventive measures announced by the State.

Title: Elyes Fakhfakh visits SAMU Northeast
Content: (TAP) – Prime Minister Elyes Fakhfakh, on Wednesday afternoon, went to the Emergency medical assistance service (SAMU) 01 of the Northeast, "Sadok Ben Jemaa", where he learnt about working conditions in the service and the emergency medical service call center (190) dedicated to citizens' questions about the coronavirus.Elyes Fakhfakh commended the efforts made by the medics and paramedics in combating the coronavirus, said a statement from the Prime Ministry.He stressed the importance of the mission of various health services, including emergency services across the territory.

Title: Comprehensive website on coronavirus launched (Prime Ministry)
Content: (TAP)– A comprehensive website providing information on the coronavirus (COVID-19) has been launched by the Prime Ministry, in cooperation with the Ministries of Health and Culture and support from civil society and private sector communication professionals.The website available on www.covid-19.tn is also accessible on an official Facebook page www.facebook.com/covid19tunisia, the Prime Ministry said in a statement Wednesday.It provides a set of medical information intended for citizens on health protection, home-quarantine and infection case reports , in addition to a set of statistical data based on information communicated by the Ministry of Health and the unit monitoring the spread of the virus.The website also features practical information, including useful phone numbers accessible to the public, as well as the latest presidential and government decisions concerning the national plan to combat the COVID-19.
